explanation:
You must inspect the implementations of all functions called (directly or via the static call graph) from OS_Application_Startup because any of them may invoke standard <string.h> routines (memcpy/memmove/memset/strcmp/strcpy/strlen/etc.) or manipulate buffers passed into/out of OS_Application_Startup. For each symbol: 

- OS_API_Init and its initializers (OS_ObjectIdInit, OS_API_Impl_Init, OS_TaskAPI_Init, OS_QueueAPI_Init, OS_BinSemAPI_Init, OS_CountSemAPI_Init, OS_MutexAPI_Init, OS_ModuleAPI_Init, OS_TimeBaseAPI_Init, OS_TimerCbAPI_Init, OS_FileAPI_Init, OS_DirAPI_Init, OS_FileSysAPI_Init, OS_ConsoleAPI_Init, OS_CondVarAPI_Init, OS_NetworkAPI_Init, OS_SocketAPI_Init): these are listed as callees in the static graph and may perform initialization that uses string operations or copy/format routines; their buffer usage and length checks must be reviewed.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: called (directly or transitively) from OS_API_Init and OS_ApplicationExit in the graph; test stubs and handler code frequently manipulate data and may call memcpy/strncpy or similar—inspect for bounds handling.

- OS_ApplicationExit and UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData: OS_Application_Startup’s graph includes ApplicationExit; examine ApplicationExit and its UT-related helpers because they can operate on test-context buffers or strings.

- UtTest_EarlyInit and UtList_Create: Early init routines may allocate or initialize lists/strings; list creation/initialization code can call string functions or set sizes that affect later usage.

- UT_BSP_Setup, OS_BSP_GetArgC, OS_BSP_GetArgV, UT_BSP_DoText: BSP setup reads/processes argv/argc and prints text. Argument handling and text output often use string functions—check for safe indexing, length calculations and safe copies.

- UtAssert_BeginTest, UT_BSP_Lock, UT_BSP_Unlock, UT_BSP_StartTestSegment: begin-test routines and BSP lock/unlock wrappers may build or log test names (strings) and call formatting or copy functions—verify they do not write past buffers passed into them.

- UtTest_Setup: user-provided setup hook (no callees listed) can still contain string operations. It must be inspected directly for any <string.h> usage.

- UtAssert_EndTest, UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport: end-test/reporting functions likely format/print results and manipulate test-segment strings and buffers. They are high-risk locations for strncpy/strcpy/memcpy misuse.

In short, to decide whether OS_Application_Startup violates the MISRA rule you must analyze the source of every called symbol above (and their callees) that could use standard string/memory routines or accept/return string/buffer pointers so you can verify sizes, length checks, and that no call can access beyond object bounds.
